import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = np.linspace(0, 2 * np.pi, 100)  
y = np.sin(x)  


plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
plt.plot(x, y, label='sin(x)', color='blue')
plt.title('Sine Curve using Matplotlib')
plt.xlabel('x values')
plt.ylabel('y values')
plt.grid(True)
plt.legend()
plt.show()

flowchart LR
  A[Write Something] --> B(Editor review the content)
  B --> C{Does the content need revision?}
  C --> D[No, then publish the content]
  C --> E[Yes, then go back to step A]
  E --> A



A simple mermaid diagram for publishing a work.

title: Demo
text:
Some citing demos

The subject of quantum computing brings together ideas from classical information theory, computer science, and quantum physics.(Steane 1998)
Key challenges will be the realization of high-efficiency sources of indistinguishable single photons, low-loss, scalable optical circuits, high-efficiency single-photon detectors, and low-loss interfacing of these components. (O’brien 2007)

title: Demo
text:
Python Plot Demo


Code

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Create an array of x values from -10 to 10
x = np.linspace(-10, 10, 400)

# Compute the corresponding y values
y = x**2

# Plot the function
plt.plot(x, y, label="y = x^2")
plt.title("Plot of y = x^2")
plt.xlabel("x")
plt.ylabel("y")
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()
